Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Environmental Engineering Solutions for Pollution Prevention (EESPP-REU)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This renewal Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Buffalo trains undergraduate researchers to address regional and global pollution prevention concerns within 3 themes: detection, source control, and remediation. Inherent with pollution prevention studies is the potential for societal benefits through improvements to human health or economics. Consistent with the program's research themes, projects may identify pollutants that were previously unrecognized, develop control technologies that limit air or water pollution emissions, or remediate sites that threaten human health. Research projects in this REU Site integrate engineering and science to solve pollution prevention issues relevant to the Buffalo-Niagara region and the globe. Each project is expected to have an immediate impact on environmental or human health and/or the economy of western New York. Students from underrepresented groups including women, minorities, and students with minimal exposure to STEM research from local, regional and national colleges or universities will be recruited.

During the ten-week summer program students are paired with a research mentor to conduct transformative pollution prevention research and make focused contributions to faculty projects in thematic research clusters addressing pollutant detection, source control, and remediation. These themes, considered together, address the wider "Pollution Prevention" focus of this REU program. Weekly group meetings of the REU cohort foster student-student communications using training workshops and professional or social networking opportunities. A community service program, piloted and improved throughout the previous two REU programs, will continue to be implemented in this REU program to provide concrete evidence of societal impact. A concluding Research Symposium, as well as support for post-REU conference presentations and publications, provides students opportunities to hone their communication skills, disseminate research results and expand opportunities for knowledge advancement. The REU program stresses its graduate school enrollment assessment by providing GRE prep training to interested participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Environmental Engineering Solutions for Pollution Prevention (EESPP) summer REU Site at the State University of New York - University at Buffalo supported 26 undergraduate students and one middle school teacher (through a Research Experiences for Teachers supplement) from 2016 through 2019. This was the third iteration (i.e., 9 years) of an Environmental Engineering led NSF REU site at the University at Buffalo.

Intellectual Merit:  Over 10 weeks each summer, participants completed impactful environmental research across three themes: pollutant detection/measurement, pollution control, and remediation. Student projects were diverse, as engaged faculty mentors came from 5 academic departments at the University at Buffalo, including Civil, Structural, and Environmental Engineering, Chemical and Biological Engineering, Chemistry, Geology, and Geography. REU participant research addressed globally important topics in the environmental realm at a level sufficient to contribute to publications and conference presentations. In total, 4 peer reviewed publications were generated as a result of this research and more than half of the participants described their research findings at academic or professional research conferences across the country. During this funding cycle, 2 student participants received NSF Graduate Research Fellowships to continue their research careers in graduate school.

Broader Impacts:  Inherent with pollution prevention studies is the potential for benefit to society through improvements to environmental and human health and/or economic gains associated with optimized pollution control technologies. Completed research projects were consistent with this broad objective, and results described in publications and research presentations highlight the far-reaching impact of the research that was completed by the REU participants. Additionally, over the duration of the project, four community service activities were completed, including working on new science education modules with K-12 science teachers and contributing to wetland restoration efforts at a local park. In total, more than 80 student-hours of volunteer time were generated, benefiting both the local non-profits and the student participants involved in the REU program. Finally, the program supported the much-needed growth of diversity in STEM fields, including engineering, through targeted participant recruitment. For example, 73% (19/26) of students in the REU program were female.
